content:
The most underrated skill of a founder?

Self-awareness.

You want to scale your startup?

Start by owning this painful truth:

Your business will NEVER outgrow you.

After 6+ years building my agency, I came to accept a harsh reality:

Stubbornness kills momentum.

Control crushes creativity.

Ego destroys trust.

Each of these ugly truths was a barrier I personally created.

But breaking them down wasn't just good for business;

It was ESSENTIAL for survival.

And here's what happened when I finally chose to get uncomfortable:

✔ My team stepped up.

✔ We scaled beyond 50 employees.

✔ I rediscovered my original "why."

So here's the real question:

What's holding YOU back?

P.S. The journey to building a great company starts with the messy work of building YOU.

topic.topic: Leading with vulnerability: Redefining strength in modern leadership

original_post:
If you want to be a respected leader…

Don’t just build your company.

Build yourself first.

🔥 Leadership isn’t about knowing everything.
It’s about knowing yourself.

After years of climbing the entrepreneurship ladder, I realized something crucial:

📍 My company could only grow as much as I did.

But that meant confronting ugly truths:
- My need to control everything
- My fear of being vulnerable
- My toxic habit of valuing busyness over well-being

Each breakthrough felt painful—like shedding layers of an identity that no longer fit.

Yet, on the other side came rewards:

✅ A team empowered to lead
✅ An agency that scaled without breaking me
✅ A company culture rooted in trust, not fear

Today, I believe the most underrated skill of a founder isn’t hiring or strategy.

It’s self-awareness.

So, ask yourself:
- What part of yourself is holding your business back?
- What uncomfortable truth are you avoiding?

Remember, growth rarely feels good. But it’s always worth it.

The journey to building a great company starts with the messy process of building you.

What uncomfortable truth about yourself feels most needed to confront right now?
feedback: To elevate the post to publish-ready standards, consider restructuring the narrative to have a clearer hook, value, and close sequence. Deepen the exploration of self-awareness as the underrated skill of a founder and provide more tangible examples or insights from your journey. Enhance engagement potential by sparking curiosity or emotion through more specific and impactful storytelling. Align the tone and writing style more closely with the bold yet grounded and minimal but deep traits of the brand voice. Additionally, ensure the post maintains a professional and strategic tone suitable for LinkedIn.

content:
I used to believe that perfection was the goal.

That a flawless plan, an elegant execution, and a polished image were the keys to success.

I spent years striving for it—losing sleep over small details, second-guessing my decisions, and thinking that showing any cracks meant I was failing.

Then I started my own business.

And every assumption I had about success shattered.

Now I see that perfectionism isn’t just an ineffective strategy. It’s a cage we build around ourselves.

The real differentiator? Resilience.

The ability to keep going when everything feels heavy.
To adapt when plans crumble.
To stay open when the universe keeps throwing obstacles in your path.

Here’s the bizarre part: You can be highly competent and still get demolished by entrepreneurial challenges.

But if you develop a resilient mindset?
If you refuse to quit, even when it’s slow, awkward, and uncomfortable?
If you embrace the messiness of building something meaningful?

You become unstoppable.

So now I embrace the uncertainty. The chaos. The mistakes.

Because they aren't signs that I'm doing it wrong. They're signs that I'm doing it right.

What about you? 

Are you building something? Give yourself permission to be a mess and keep going anyway.

topic.topic: Choosing resilience over perfection: lessons from navigating uncertainty and discomfort as a solo entrepreneur

feedback: To further improve, consider enhancing the hook at the beginning to grab the reader's attention even more. Additionally, adding a more explicit tie-back to the Suryadev Singh Rathore personal brand brief could strengthen the post's alignment with the brand's objectives and themes. Overall, with some minor tweaks, this post is nearly ready for publishing.

content:
A bold truth:

The people who think they need perfect plans never actually start.

I know this because I used to be one of them.

The myth of grand designs convinces so many talented people that if they don't have every step mapped out, they should wait.

But here's what I've learned building companies and my identity from scratch: real entrepreneurship isn't about blueprints.

It's about momentum against uncertainty.

You don't figure out what works on paper. You discover it while moving.

Every meaningful project I've started began with more questions than answers—because the answers don't exist until you start.

Stop waiting for the stars to align.

They never will.

The best builders act on 30% clarity and adjust along the way. The rest stay stuck because the vision isn't perfect enough.

Now tell me: what project in your life needs the "just start" approach?

topic.topic: The myth of perfect plans: Why starting without all the answers leads to true entrepreneurship

feedback: To improve the post, consider adding more personal insights and lived-through lessons to make the content more original and engaging. Dive deeper into the nuances of starting without perfect plans and provide specific examples or anecdotes from your experience. Incorporate elements of vulnerability, clarity, and personal power to align better with the brand's core objectives and target audience. Integrate unique value propositions such as the 'builder-first mindset' and 'cultural relevance' to make the post stand out. Overall, the post has potential with slight adjustments to enhance clarity and engagement.

content:
I was at an event recently when a former colleague approached me.

"Remember when you left the company?" he began. "Everyone thought you'd made a mistake."

I smiled, recalling their exact words... 

"You'll regret this."

What they couldn't see was the bigger picture: my decision wasn't just about leaving a job. 

It was about prioritizing my health, integrity and the kind of leader I wanted to become.

We spend so long climbing the wrong ladders... convinced status, salary and "success" are the same thing.

But they aren't. 

Real leadership isn't about titles or tech stacks or bottom lines. 

It's about creating environments where people can thrive, where values aren't just slogans, and where profit isn't the only measure of success.

If you're building something — be it a business, a team, or a career — remember this:

The right strategy is simple: 

Choose people over numbers, culture over convenience, impact over ego.

Because if you get this part wrong, everything else you build will be just another assembly line.

♻️ What's the part of leadership they don't teach you in business school?

topic.topic: Choosing people over profit — the only strategy that never fails
